Behind yon western hills the God of Day</br>To distant climes his burnish'd car display'd;</br>When lost in Slumber's silken arms I lay,</br>And sportive Fancy wanton'd round my head.</br>Soon as the goddess wav'd the magic wand,</br>What scenes of wild enchantment glow'd around;</br>A new creation smil'd at her command,</br>And double suns arose with purple glories crown'd.

Wide o'er the blissful scene methought awhile</br>I rov'd in grots, and groves, and gardens fair,</br>Where nought was seen save what might grief beguile,</br>And heal the woe-worn heart of deep despair:</br>There grew to grace the smoothly-shaven green,</br>Immingled flow'rs of ev'ry gaudy dye,</br>And spicy groves, with crystal brooks between,</br>Sabean odours shed, beneath a cloudless sky.

In pleasure lost, along the happy plain</br>Heedless I stray'd, till soon resounded near</br>Harmonious sounds that thrill'd thro' ev'ry vein;</br>Sounds that might sooth a list'ning seraph's ear.</br>Not mightier transports struck the Grecian band;</br>Nor stronger tumults seiz'd the madd'ning soul,</br>When syrens tempted to the fatal strand,</br>While the charm'd Ocean ceas'd his wond'ring waves to roll.

Onward I mus'd, till, sudden to my sight,</br>A splendid palace rear'd its lofty head;</br>Its glitt'ring front with golden pillars bright,</br>Round which the vine her wanton tendrils spread.</br>No churlish door the courtly mansion knew;</br>Its friendly arch invites the fearful guest;</br>And music warbled, as I nearer drew,</br>"Here joy for ever reigns — O enter and be blest."

Glad I pursu'd the path as hope inspir'd,</br>Mix'd with the croud the promis'd bliss to gain,</br>Where jointly press'd, with equal ardour fir'd,</br>Plenty's mad sons, and Mis'ry's meagre train.</br>Quick as the lightning's flash, a boundless stream</br>Of heav'nly splendor struck my dazzled eye,</br>Bright as when Iris courts the solar beam,</br>And spread her varied vest across the show'ry sky.

Where'er I turn'd, to please the fickle mind,</br>Some darling pleasure still arose to view:</br>Along the pictur'd walls had Art design'd</br>The tale as bold as Raphael's pencil drew;</br>Here, from Ganges, led his frantic files,</br>In merry pomp, the ivy-crown'd God;</br>There, from the sea, the new born Queen of Smiles</br>In softer colours shone, in naked beauty glow'd.

Here genial Plenty fix'd her constant care;</br>Profusely kind, an endless feast she spread;</br>To crown the loaded board with ample fare,</br>Daily she bade a thousand victims bleed;</br>Gave gaily-tinctur'd fruits, a various store,</br>Brought from a thousand climes to tempt the taste,</br>Fairer than those on India's happy shore,</br>Nor fam'd Columbus' world can boast a like repast.

And soon appear'd a rosy-featur'd train;</br>With glee-full heart they quaff'd the nectar'd bowl,</br>And loud they laugh'd, nor heeded future pain,</br>But cheer'd with frequent cups the sickly soul.</br>Eager they wak'd the sorrow-soothing lyre;</br>To Music's voice they joined the sprightly song;</br>And while the revel-raised raptures fire,</br>Swift steal the the jovial hours on downy wings along.

And next, of youthful nymphs a bevy fair,</br>With yielding looks, and pleading smiles, advance;</br>In artful ringlets wav'd their rose-crown'd hair,</br>As round they trod the light fantastic dance.</br>Bare to the bold admirer's lawless gaze</br>Luxuriant rose their undulating breast,</br>As to the lute they sang, in am'rous lays,</br>How Jove's immortal son the Lydian's pow'r confest.

Sweet flow'd th' impassion'd strain — with quick'ned throes</br>Wild thro' my veins the crimson current flew,</br>When, from her adamantine throne, arose</br>A Goddess, clad in robes of gaudiest hue;</br>Tho' youth had fled, a captivating grace</br>Majestic, o'er th' untimely ruin hung;</br>Still roll'd her eye, still artful bloom'd her face,</br>Nor yet forgat to charm her smooth persuasive tongue.

"Come, O my son," the gentle Queen began;</br>"Come, long-sought youth, and welcome to my breast;</br>Well has thy bark o'er life's uncertain main</br>Scap'd the rough storm, and found the land of rest.</br>Far from the dreary thorn-spread ways of woe,</br>Here Pleasure's primrose-paths thy steps invite;</br>No eyes shall here with tears of sorrow flow,</br>Ill they befit the scenes of ever-new delight.

"See scatter'd round the choicest gifts of heav'n;</br>Heav'n's chiefest care these happy seats employ;</br>Taste freely, then, the gifts so freely giv'n,</br>Nor meanly sin by fearing to enjoy.</br>Go, join in woodbine bow'rs the shouting band,</br>Let Laughter loose, and from the mantling vine</br>Its comeliest clusters rend with fearless hand,</br>And round thine am'rous brows the rosy wreath entwine.

"Let not the dread of future ills alloy,</br>With impotent presage, the present bliss,</br>But learn amid the virgin choir to toy,</br>Sport in yon shades, and print the balmy kiss:</br>Go then, my son, where beauty points thy way,</br>Boldly thro' Joy's unbounded empire rove,</br>And let thine unreluctant heart obey</br>Love's kind impulsive laws, and all his raptures prove."

Awhile she paus'd — nor let the frozen frown</br>Of bearded age too harshly chide the bard,</br>If haply Truth's impartial voice should own,</br>That pleas'd he list'ned, and with transport heard.</br>For sure with thoughtless ease the passive mind</br>Had hurried on in Passion's mad career,</br>Had not some Pow'r, to human frailty kind,</br>Deep shook the splendid dome, and call'd aloud — "Forbear."

Wond'ring I turn'd where heav'nly Wisdom stood;</br>No tinsel trappings deck'd the graceful maid;</br>With native beauty's awful charms endow'd,</br>Around her brows celestial glories play'd.</br>While angry pity flush'd her cheek, she cry'd,</br>"Quick from these shores thy wand'ring steps refrain,</br>Where fell Excess her vot'ries seeks to guide</br>To Ruin's gaping gulph, thro' Folly's wide domain.

"To tempt thy feet from Virtue's paths aside,</br>Know that the Sorc'ress weaves her guileful snare,</br>And rears her groves, and specious bow'rs, to hide</br>The near but doleful regions of Despair.</br>As thro' the darksome night the meteor's blaze</br>Deludes the weary trav'ller from his home,</br>And cheerful pours its momentary rays,</br>Then leaves the hapless wretch thro' rocks and wilds to roam.

"For ev'n beneath the fragrant myrtle's shade,</br>When bounds thine heart at Riot's loud alarms,</br>When by the toyful hand of Dalliance led,</br>The loose-rob'd maid resigns her heighten'd charms;</br>Shall sad Reflection shed the sudden tear,</br>Shall sharp Repentance wound thy bleeding breast;</br>Ev'n Music's mirthful lyre shall fright thine ear,</br>The cloudless sky shall frown, and cloy the tasteless feast.

"Unreal pleasures here enchant thine eyes;</br>Early they perish with the fleeting hour:</br>As insect tribes, that sport in summer skies,</br>Bide not the northern blast or wintry show'r.</br>To nobler joys th' eternal mind aspires,</br>Joys that shall last when Time's short reign is o'er,</br>When the pale sun shall lose his aged fires,</br>Forget his wonted course, and set to rise nor more."

'Twas thus the mild majestic Goddess spoke,</br>And upward straight on hasty pinions fled;</br>The trembling palace felt the thunder's stroke,</br>The blasted bow'r the lightning's rage display'd.</br>How vanish'd from my sight th' enchanted scene,</br>Where late I rov'd, in pleasing transport lost!</br>No blooming flow'r bedeck'd the blighted green,</br>But swept the whirlwind bleak along the clouded coast.

No more to grace the lovely spot were found</br>Its spicy groves, and grots, and gardens fair:</br>No suns arose, with purple glories crown'd,</br>But yawn'd the dreary caverns of Despair.</br>Loathsome to sight, there crawl'd the bloated toad,</br>And there the screech-owl nurs'd her num'rous young;</br>There sought the crested snake his curs'd abode,</br>Slow dragg'd his writhed train, and roll'd his forked tongue.

Ah!  who can paint what complicated woes,</br>What hell-born fears, my tortur'd soul oppress'd,</br>Till the big terror banish'd sleep, and rose</br>The day's bright regent in the crimson'd east.</br>Each dreadful object Fancy still reviews,</br>Tho' frighted oft she sickens at the sight;</br>And faithful Mem'ry prompts the fearful muse</br>To tell, in simple strains, the visions of the night.</br>
